title: Drapers investigates: how fashion retail is carbon offsetting - Drapers
summary: The article discusses how fashion businesses are using carbon offsetting to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and play a part in reducing their carbon footprint. It highlights the challenges and controversies surrounding carbon offsetting, as well as alternative approaches such as carbon insetting and direct investment in reducing emissions within supply chains.
green_innovation: FALSE. The article focuses on carbon offsetting practices within the fashion industry to address emissions, which, while environmentally beneficial, do not introduce significant new methods or technologies that enable a sustainable transformation beyond existing practices.
business_innovation: TRUE. The article discusses the adoption of new practices, such as carbon offsetting, carbon insetting, and direct investment in emissions reduction, by fashion businesses to enhance their sustainability efforts and reduce their environmental impact, showcasing a change from previous approaches.
green_product: TRUE. The article highlights how fashion brands are engaging in carbon offsetting, carbon insetting, and sustainable practices to reduce the environmental impact of their products throughout the life cycle, aligning with the definition of green products through eco-friendly measures like biodegradability and resource conservation.
green_process: TRUE. The article showcases how fashion businesses are implementing green processes such as carbon offsetting, direct investment in emissions reduction, and sustainable manufacturing practices to minimize environmental impacts, conserve resources, and reduce emissions, in line with the definition of green processes.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 424320 - Men's and Boys' Clothing and Furnishings Merchant Wholesalers, 424330 - Women's, Children's, and Infants' Clothing and Accessories Merchant Wholesalers, 424340 - Footwear Merchant Wholesalers, 424990 - Other Miscellaneous Nondurable Goods Merchant Wholesalers
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it primarily focuses on the challenges and nuances of carbon offsetting, carbon insetting, and sustainable practices within the fashion industry without providing misleading or deceptive claims about environmental benefits.

title: Govt to buy up €3 million worth of carbon credits from Slovakia to meet climate targets - TheJournal.ie
summary: The Government of Ireland has approved the purchase of nearly €3 million worth of carbon credits from Slovakia to meet 2020 emission targets by 17 February, which aligns with EU regulations on greenhouse gas emissions reduction.
green_innovation: FALSE: The article does not discuss a new or significantly improved environmentally sustainable process or product innovation.
business_innovation: FALSE: The focus of the article is on meeting emission targets through the purchase of carbon credits rather than on introducing new products or processes.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not detail the design, manufacturing, or environmental impact reduction throughout the life cycle of a specific product.
green_process: FALSE: The article does not provide information on a specific method or technique to minimize environmental impacts in manufacturing or operational activities.
greenwashing: FALSE: The article discusses the purchase of carbon credits to meet emission targets, and there is no indication of false or misleading environmental claims regarding a product or practice.

title: Using blockchain to rethink systems and society - Delano.lu
summary: The article discusses three innovative companies - Survcoin, Food For Future, and Nash FintechX - each utilizing blockchain technology to address environmental and social challenges in diverse sectors such as decarbonisation, regenerative agriculture, and carbon offset markets.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article discusses innovative companies that are incorporating blockchain technology to address environmental challenges related to decarbonisation, regenerative agriculture, and carbon offset markets, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article mentions new companies and ventures such as Survcoin, Food For Future, and Nash FintechX that are implementing blockchain technology, new business models, and innovative approaches within their respective sectors, demonstrating significant deviations from traditional practices.
green_product: TRUE - The article discusses products and initiatives by the companies that aim to promote sustainability, such as Survcoin rewarding decarbonisation efforts, Food For Future supporting regenerative agriculture, and Nash FintechX focusing on a blockchain-based carbon market, all designed to reduce environmental impacts throughout their life cycles.
green_process: TRUE - The article highlights processes employed by the companies, including implementing blockchain technology, digitising supply chains, promoting precision farming, and creating transparency in carbon markets, to minimize environmental impacts, conserve resources, and enhance sustainability in their operations.
official_company_name: Survcoin, Food For Future, Nash FintechX
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 511210 - Software Publishers, 112330 - Olive Oil Production, 523920 - Portfolio Management, 511130 - Book Publishers
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not indicate any false or misleading environmental claims; instead, it focuses on genuine efforts and innovations by the companies to tackle sustainability challenges.

title: 55 Women-Owned Businesses That Give Back & Do Good - Good Good Good
